title-group.article-title: The role of early multislice computed tomography in major trauma

abstract.p: Whole-body multislice spiral computed tomography (MSCT) has become a very important dignostic tool in the management of patients with multiple injuries. Many reports exist which demonstrate the feasibility and the benefit when using whole-body MSCT in the early phase of in-hospital management of trauma patients. Even in hemodynamically instable patients (except cardiac arrest), whole-body MSCT can be used and is a safe diagnostic procedure. While the diagnostic superiority of multislice computed tomography is proven for different organ regions (e.g. head/brain, chest, abdomen, pelvis and spine), its use as a single whole-body scan is still part of an ongoing discussion. Especially concerns about radiation exposure are the reason for uncertainty about when using whole-body trauma scan. Predefined scan protocols and individual positioning of patients may help to keep radiation dose as minimal as possible. To justify higher radiation dose, the indication must be chosen appropriately. Therefore, the use of a sensitive and specific triage scheme seems to be reasonable. Overscanning patients with minor trauma needs to be avoided, while the benefit for patients with severe multiple injuries is obvious.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The early in-hospital management of patients with multiple injuries and major trauma is generally based on three principles: (1) life-threatening conditions have to be treated according to their priority, (2) complete diagnostic workup of the head, neck, chest, abdomen and pelvis is mandatory and (3) an interdisciplinary ‘next-hours’-treatment plan based on patient’s clinical conditions and the findings of the radiological examination has to be created (Beck et al., 2004; Bernhard et al., 2007; Clarke et al., 2002; Harris, 2001; Nast-Kolb and Ruchholtz, 1999; Nast-Kolb et al., 1994; Van Olden et al., 2004). Therefore, the initial diagnostic workup is one important element of a well-defined trauma management.

Traditionally, conventional radiography and ultrasound is completed by organ-focused computed tomography (CT) (conventional trauma protocol). Usually, the trauma suite is equipped with an X-ray unit and a mobile ultrasound system. With arrival of the patient, the trauma team starts with priority orientated resuscitation (in general, according to the ATLS® approach). After life-threatening problems are resolved, the diagnostic work-up starts with plain films of the chest, the pelvis and the cervical spine and a focused abdominal ultrasound on trauma (FAST). Additional plain films are made depending on further suspected injuries. Reassessment of the patient is carried out and necessary emergency interventions are performed before the patient is transferred to the radiology department for organ-focused CT. The diagnostic period is finished with the end of the CT examination. The patient’s condition and the findings on the CT scan define the further treatment plan (Beck et al., 2004; Kuhne et al., 2004; Nast-Kolb et al., 1994; Ruchholtz et al., 2002).

In the last few years, CT has gained importance in the early diagnostic phase of trauma care, especially the development of multislice spiral computed tomography (MSCT) has led to substantial refinement in the diagnostic work-up (Kanz et al., 2004; Kloppel et al., 2002; Low et al., 1997; Philipp et al., 2003; Rieger et al., 2002). One of the most important technical improvements is time gain using predefined scan protocols and standardized scan parameters (Kulama, 2004). Whole-body MSCT produces high-resolution images; volume imaging allows multiplanar reconstruction and three-dimensional imaging. Such whole-body MSCT can rapidly reveal all relevant injuries (Figures 1 to 7) (Albrecht et al., 2004; Kloppel et al., 2002; Low et al., 1997; Rieger et al., 2002), resulting in an immediate treatment plan. As a result, a growing number of trauma centres have started to use whole-body MSCT as the primary diagnostic tool, even in haemodynamically instable patients (Bernhard et al., 2007; Hilbert et al., 2007; Weninger et al., 2007; Wurmb et al., 2005). sec.title: History and development of whole-body MSCT trauma protocols
sec.p: Low et al. (1997) first described the use of whole-body helical CT for rapid primary diagnostic in multiple injured patients. The authors found that helical CT was a reliable and rapid method to diagnose the most important injuries and that CT scanning in early trauma care is a valuable tool to improve management of the severely injured patient. Moreover, the authors found a markedly reduced number of conventional X-ray examinations in those patients (Low et al., 1997). Over the next decade, several reports were published that demonstrated a benefit from early whole-body MSCT in trauma patients. In a retrospective analysis, Rieger et al. (2002) demonstrated a time gain of up to 50% when using whole-body MSCT in trauma patients. Kloppel et al. (2002) found a reduction in treatment time after changing their trauma protocol from one- to four-slice helical CT. Their opinion was that integrating whole-body MSCT in an interdisciplinary management concept would be a good compromise between examination times, diagnostic quality, emergency interventions and therapy planning. Kanz et al. (2004) prospectively evaluated a series of 125 trauma patients obtaining whole-body MSCT after a basic diagnostic with chest X-ray and FAST. Complete diagnostic work-up was finished within 30 min after admission. No life-threatening adverse event related to the CT scan was described. The authors concluded that the primary survey was not affected by the CT scan and that the time to obtain the most relevant diagnosis was markedly reduced using whole-body MSCT early in the trauma treatment course.

The first concepts with early use of whole-body MSCT had conventional radiography and FAST prior to the CT scan with the CT scanner located in the radiology department. The next step was the integration of the CT scanner directly in the trauma suite of the emergency room. Kuhnigk et al. (2004) described this new approach. A 16-row CT scanner was installed in the trauma suite. Transport of the patient to the radiology department was no longer necessary. The same concept was described by Hilbert et al. in 2007. This new approach had the goal of further reducing treatment time, eliminating redundant diagnostic studies and avoiding additional transfer of the seriously injured patient. The authors were successful in integrating the CT scan in an ATLS® approach. The primary survey was done immediately after the patients’ arrival in the emergency room and before starting the CT scan. Conventional X-ray or FAST is completely eliminated from the algorithm (Hilbert et al., 2007). Wurmb et al. (2005) published an almost identical protocol. An MSCT with a 16-row scanner was directly installed in the resuscitation room of the trauma suite (Figure 8). Any technical equipment needed for the management of severe trauma (e.g. anaesthesia machine, ventilator, complete monitoring, rapid infusion system, blood supplies, etc.) was available in the same location. Once placed on the special carbon CT and intervention table, the patient’s position does not need to be modified. Any life-saving procedure, including airway management, emergency laparotomy or thoracotomy, can be performed on the table if necessary. Before starting the CT scan, an ATLS®-based work-up was done for an initial assessment. In contrast to the algorithm published by Hilbert et al., FAST was performed in haemodynamically unstable patients prior to the CT scan. The CT scan was started when life-threatening problems had been resolved. Any device, such as respirator tubing, central venous lines, etc., was left unchanged in their position, while the mobile sliding CT gantry was moving from the head to toe of the patient (Wurmb et al., 2005) (Figure 8). sec.title: Diagnostic value of MSCT (related to organ regions)
Traumatic brain injury
sec.p: The influence of traumatic brain injury on the morbidity and mortality of trauma patients is well known and there is no doubt that CT is currently the diagnostic of choice as it allows the exact assessment of the entire brain and the skull (Kaups et al., 2004; Shackford et al., 1992; Stiell et al., 2001).

sec.title: Thoracic injuries
sec.p: The value of the thoracic CT in the assessment of trauma patients with blunt chest trauma was demonstrated by Trupka et al. (1997). In a prospective study, trauma patients with clinical or radiological signs of chest trauma were diagnosed by conventional chest X-ray and thoracic CT, and the results were compared looking for additional findings in the CT scan. It was concluded that thoracic CT was highly sensitive in detecting thoracic injuries after blunt chest trauma and was superior to routine chest X-ray in visualizing lung contusions, pneumothorax and haematothorax. The authors found a significant change in therapeutic management caused by CT scan results. They recommended thoracic CT in the initial diagnostic work-up of patients with multiple injuries and with suspected chest trauma (Trupka et al., 1997). It is well known that most injuries missed in the early phase of trauma management are abdominal or thoracic in origin (Hirshberg et al., 1994; Ledgerwood and Lucas, 1990; Nast-Kolb et al., 1993), representing the leading causes for preventable deaths in trauma patients (Johnson et al., 1986; Rieger et al., 2002). There is evidence that MSCT is superior to conventional X-ray in the diagnosis of thoracic injuries (Exadaktylos et al., 2001; Low et al., 1997; Rieger et al., 2002; Trupka et al., 1997) and therefore MSCT in trauma patients might be justified to reveal serious isolated organ injury.

sec.title: Abdominal injuries
sec.p: Intra-abdominal injuries are a common finding in blunt major trauma. Evaluation of the abdomen is difficult during the initial assessment of the trauma patient, and missed abdominal injuries are one of the leading causes of preventable death in trauma patients (Gruen et al., 2006; Houshian et al., 2002; Ochsner et al., 2000). Therefore, a proper diagnostic work-up of the abdomen is mandatory. Diagnostic peritoneal lavage, ultrasound and the CT scan are the diagnostic options for ruling out intra-abdominal injuries. While ultrasound and peritoneal lavage rely on the presence of blood or intestinal fluid in the abdomen, the CT scan might show abdominal injuries without active bleeding (Ochsner et al., 2000). Albrecht et al. (2004) compared the diagnostic accuracy of whole-body MSCT with FAST and conventional radiography. For the diagnosis of intra-abdominal injuries, they found a sensitivity of 92% for CT scan, while abdominal ultrasound had a sensitivity of 22%. Maurer et al. (2008) performed a retrospective analysis to determine the added diagnostic benefit of using whole-body MSCT in multiple trauma patients. In 275 patients, they report 112 additional relevant injuries in the abdomen that were not diagnosed by ultrasound (Maurer et al., 2008). Buhne et al. (2001) compared prospectively the impact of CT scanning and abdominal ultrasound on therapeutic decisions in patients with suspected abdominal injuries. The authors concluded that if the ultrasound is abnormal, CT scan will have an important impact on therapeutic decisions. After a negative ultrasound, a change in therapy was found in 8 out of 105 patients (Buhne et al., 2001). Houshian et al. (2002) analysed missed injuries in a level I trauma centre. They found 8.1% missed injuries in 786 patients. Missed abdominal injuries were predominant in requiring surgery. Most missed injuries were not suspected by the trauma team (60.5%), while the results of the ultrasound, radiographs and CT scan were misinterpreted by the radiologists in 34.9%. Miller et al. (2003) evaluated FAST in haemodynamically instable patients with suspected blunt abdominal injury. The authors found that the use of FAST in those patients will lead to underdiagnosis of intra-abdominal injury. They recommended the routine use of CT in haemodynamically stable patients with blunt abdominal trauma. In a review article, McGahan (2002) concluded that if free abdominal fluid is detected by ultrasound, this may indicate serious intraabdominal injury. In the absence of free fluid, there is still a significant risk for relevant injury that is not diagnosed by FAST (McGahan et al., 2002). Having the highest sensitivity and specificity, the S3-guideline of the German Society of Trauma Surgeons clearly recommends the routine use of MSCT in patients with blunt abdominal trauma (S3-Guideline German Society of Trauma Surgeons, www.awmf.org).

sec.title: Injuries of the spine
sec.p: MSCT is invaluable in the evaluation of the traumatized spine; it is superior to plain films delineating extension of fracture fragments into the spine canal (Gestring et al., 2002; McGahan et al., 2002; Watura et al., 2004). For clearing the cervical spine, MSCT is superior to plain film radiography (Daffner, 2001; Griffen et al., 2003; Jelly et al., 2000; Obenauer et al., 2002; Watura et al., 2004), especially in intubated patients where the craniocervical junction and the lower cervical spine is often difficult to evaluate (Watura et al., 2004). Wintermark et al. (2003) conducted a prospective study to determine whether MSCT might replace conventional radiography and be performed alone in severe trauma patients for depiction of thoracolumbar spine fractures. They concluded that MSCT can replace plain radiography and can be performed alone in patients who have sustained severe trauma. For that reason, MSCT seems to be justified in all trauma patients where there is a suspicion of spine fractures, especially in sedated and intubated patients. A different procedure was proposed by Watura et al. (2004). The authors stated that replacing plain films with MSCT would significantly increase radiation exposure of whom the vast majority will have normal spines that are adequately examined by plain film radiographs. They recommended MSCT in patients with either abnormal plain radiographs requiring further evaluation or in trauma patients with nondiagnostic plain radiographs and possible fractures. Brown et al. (2005) adopted spiral CT as the primary modality for the diagnosis of spine fractures. The authors stated that routine plain radiographs of the spine are not necessary in the evaluation of blunt trauma patients when spiral CT is used. In a recent meta-analyses, Holmes and Akkinepalli (2005) found no randomized controlled trial but ample evidence that CT significantly outperforms plain radiography as a screening test in patients with high risk of cervical spine injury.

sec.title: Injury of the pelvis
sec.p: Haemorrhage from pelvic injuries is a potential lethal complication in major trauma victims. In haemodynamically instable patients, it is often difficult to prioritize the major site of bleeding especially when suspected abdominal injuries are present in combination with pelvic injuries. In those cases, FAST can reveal free abdominal fluid and this finding might initiate immediate laparotomy. This might be fatal if haemoperitoneum is found to be secondary to intraperitoneal leakage of retroperitoneal bleeding (Tien et al., 2007). Plain radiographs alone have limited sensitivity for detection of pelvic fractures compared with CT (Guillamondegui et al., 2002; Watura et al., 2004), and the visualization of the pelvic vascular and organ structures by CT is invaluable (Berg et al., 1996; Resnik et al., 1992). Plain films as a routine screening device seem to be unnecessary in patients with suspected multiple injuries who are to be imaged immediately by CT (Stewart et al., 2002).

sec.title: Indication for whole-body MSCT
sec.p:
As discussed, the superiority of MSCT is widely accepted for organ-focused diagnostics after trauma; however, the appropriate indication for initial whole-body MSCT remains unclear (Wurmb et al., 2007) and is part of an ongoing discussion. When whole-body MSCT is used for initial diagnostic work-up in trauma patients, it is important to identify patients with suspected serious injuries in order to justify the higher radiation dose. In our level I trauma centre, the indication for whole-body MSCT is set using a systematic triage rule. It is based on a triage system that was published by Nast-Kolb et al. (1994). Using our trauma protocol, we screen trauma patients in a standardized manner to decide on diagnostic measures. The scheme consists of three categories with different parameters in each category. The triage rule is shown in Table 1. If one single parameter is found to be positive, serious injuries in one or more organ systems are suspected (Nast-Kolb et al., 1994). The CT trauma protocol will be initiated. If the patient fails to meet one of the criteria, the conventional trauma protocol including conventional plain film radiography of the cervical spine, the chest, the pelvis and ultrasound of the abdomen is initiated. If the conventional trauma protocol is inconclusive or reveals injuries that need to be addressed with CT, an organ-focused CT examination is performed afterwards. Table 1.

Wurmb et al. (2007) performed a retrospective data analysis to evaluate the accuracy of the triage scheme. The authors defined overtriage as the use of MSCT trauma protocol in patients with an Injury Severity Score (ISS) <16 and undertriage as conventional trauma protocol used in patients with ISS ≥16. Appropriate indication was assumed when patients had ISS ≥16 and the whole-body MSCT was used. A total of 59 (70%) patients undergoing the CT trauma protocol (n=85) had ISS values ≥16. Overtriage (ISS <16) occurred in 26 (30%) patients with 9 patients suffering from significant injuries. Undertriage (ISS ≥16) occurred in 2 of 35 patients (6%). It was concluded that overtriage seemed to be acceptable since 35% of the overtriaged patients had significant injuries diagnosed by whole-body MSCT. In order to find the most relevant and independent predictive factors helping in reducing the risk of overscanning trauma patients, further research is necessary. A different way to initiate whole-body MSCT in trauma patients was described by Salim et al. (2006). The authors hypothesized that liberal use of whole-body MSCT based on trauma mechanism alone is warranted, even in evaluable patients with no obvious sign of chest and abdominal injuries. In 592, evaluable patients without clinical signs for chest or abdominal injuries, they found significant abnormalities up to 19% of patients and a change in therapy in 19%. With these findings, the authors concluded that liberal use of whole-body MSCT in trauma patients is justified (Salim et al., 2006).

The authors of this article believe that further research is warranted to find the most relevant and independent predictive factors for the need of a whole-body MSCT, in order to define a favourable ratio of benefit to risk and to avoid overscanning trauma patients.

sec.title: Whole-body MSCT and outcome
sec.p: The use of whole-body MSCT during trauma resuscitation is a time-saving procedure (Boehm et al., 2004; Hilbert et al., 2007; Low et al., 1997; Weninger et al., 2007; Wurmb et al., 2009). Moreover, several studies demonstrated a benefit in outcome in those patients receiving early whole-body MSCT. Weninger et al. (2007) reported a significant reduction in in-hospital stay, in ICU stay and in ventilation days for trauma patients initially scanned with whole-body MSCT. The authors also found a significantly lower rate of organ failure in those patients. Fung Kon Jin et al. (2008) evaluated the influence of an MSCT-based trauma algorithm on the outcome of patients with severe traumatic brain injury. They found a significant reduction in mortality in favour of those trauma patients treated according to the CT-based algorithm. They also described a trend towards earlier neurosurgical intervention. In a retrospective study, Wurmb et al. (2011) investigated the influence of a whole-body MSCT trauma algorithm on the time interval before starting emergency surgery. They found that emergency surgery of patients with major trauma was initiated significantly earlier when using an MSCT trauma scan. An influence on survival was not found in this study. Hilbert et al. (2007) and Bernhard et al. (2007) reported a trend towards reduction of mortality while using initial trauma scan in their trauma algorithm and Huber-Wagner et al. (2009) were the first authors who clearly demonstrated an increased probability of survival in patients with multiple traumas when using whole-body CT as a standard diagnostic tool in the early resuscitation phase.

sec.title: Radiation dose and MSCT
sec.p: Main concern when using whole-body MSCT for screening trauma patients is the higher radiation dose. One appropriate measure to reduce radiation dose is the use of well-defined scan protocols (Fanucci et al., 2007; Ptak et al., 2003). A comparison of radiation exposure from whole-body MSCT and conventional radiography with organ-specific CT was published by Wedegartner et al. (2004). These authors calculated the radiation dose of different diagnostic procedures. First was whole-body MSCT, second was conventional plain film radiography including chest, cervical, thoracic and lumbar spine in two views, as well as pelvis, third was conventional radiography in combination with organ-specific CT. The CT examination included head with cervical spine (combination a), head with cervical spine and chest (combination b) or head with cervical spine and abdomen (combination c). The effective doses were 20 mSv for whole-body MSCT, 2 mSv for conventional radiography, 6.8 mSv for combination a, 10.3 mSv for combination b and 18 mSv for combination c. Considering the superiority of MSCT to plain film radiography in clearing the spine, the chest and the abdomen, the possible higher radiation dose, which is associated with MSCT employed as a diagnostic screening tool, in trauma patients might be justified.

Nevertheless, it remains a difficult question: what is best for the individual trauma patient with regard to the potential hazard of a higher radiation dose and the risk of missing pertinent injuries which might contribute to fatal outcome? Corresponding to the data of the annual report of the International Commission on Radiological Protection, the risk of fatal cancer per 10 mSV radiation dose is 1/1777 patients. In 1777 patients, we find a risk for the spontaneous development of fatal cancer in 355/1777. The risk of missing serious injuries in patients with multiple trauma is described by Houshian et al. (2002). The authors report a number of 86 missed injuries in 786 trauma patients. Four patients died due to missed injuries, seven had a fatal outcome. Most missed injuries were not suspected by the trauma team, but in 34.9% of the reported cases, the results of radiographs, ultrasound or CT scan were misinterpreted by radiologists. Therefore, 65% of the injuries probably would not have been missed using whole-body MSCT as a screening method; the risk benefit ratio is that one whole-body MSCT per 302 patients might have saved one life, while 10 mSV might be responsible for the development of one fatal cancer in 1777 patients. Gruen et al. (2006) reported two missed intra-abdominal injuries responsible for fatal outcome in 2594 trauma deaths. Hence, MSCT might have saved one life in 1297 patients as it is supposed to be the gold standard in diagnosis of the traumatized thorax and abdomen, especially in those blunt abdominal injuries with minimal or even without intraperitoneal fluid, which are at high risk of being missed by conventional diagnostic tests.

Despite the possible benefit for patients with severe trauma, an indiscriminate use of CT for patients with minor trauma is not justified (Fabian, 2009). Furthermore in patients with suspected major trauma, the CT-related dose in the individual patient needs to be as low as possible (Brenner and Hall, 2007). In this context, several studies have recently been published (Brink et al., 2008; Karlo et al., 2011; Loewenhardt et al., 2011). Loewnhardt et al. (2011) reported a reduction of effective dose up to 22% when the patients’ arms were raised during the chest and abdomen scan. The authors concluded that an individual positioning algorithm may lead to relevant reduction of radiation dose in severely injured patients receiving MSCT.

sec.title: Summary
sec.p: Whole-body MSCT is a valuable diagnostic tool in patients with multiple injuries. It is a time-saving procedure with the powerful opportunity to reveal all the relevant diagnoses very early during trauma resuscitation. For an appropriate setup, the use of MSCT needs to be part of a well-defined trauma algorithm and the scanner needs to be placed in or very close to the resuscitation area. To justify the higher radiation dose, the indication must be appropriately chosen. Therefore, the use of a sensitive and specific triage scheme seems to be reasonable. Overscanning patients with minor trauma needs to be avoided, while the benefit for patients with severe multiple injuries is obvious.
